channel.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
channel.description:
I started on rewriting CPFP in python, based on the Tails script at https://git-tails.immerda.ch/tails/plain/config/chroot_local-includes/usr/local/sbin/tor-controlport-filter.
Still at an early stage, but it looks promising. I am posting early because, in the course of my tests, I have encountered many errors using a slightly modified of "tor_bootstrap_check.py". I have added some additional exceptions handling. https://github.com/troubadoour/anon-shared-helper-scripts/commit/268fa666cabc16aefb9025420f52224f0e031d0d.
Might be handy for debugging Tor protocol.
I will come back soon with more details on the progress.

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
github.com/Whonix/anon-gw-anonymizer-config

No longer open Tor ControlPort 9051 on Whonix-Gateway. 

No longer required, since tor-arm now supports Tor cookie file authentication.
We don't care about Vidalia, since it has long been deprecated...
by adrelanos on 12:24AM - 23 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 0 additions and 12 deletions.

Read full topic

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
(Tor control protocol)

The default anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor config file should explain most of what anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor does.

https://github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor/blob/master/etc/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor.d/30_anon-dist.conf

Now it is almost possible for python-stem based applications to do Tor Control Auth Cookie authentication. One small piece for this is still missing.

We would have to whitelist protocolinfo 1 by default also. It would answer (and relay back to the workstation):

250-PROTOCOLINFO 1
250-AUTH METHODS=COOKIE,SAFECOOKIE COOKIEFILE="/var/run/tor/control.authcookie"
250-VERSION Tor="0.2.8.7"
250 OK

Does that look alright? Should we whitelist protoclinfo? Or does anything speak against this? If so, we could implement a hardcoded, fake answer, another “lie”.

Read full topic
item.source: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Since https://github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor functionality interacts with https://github.com/Whonix/control-port-filter-python, I am also discussing anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor here.

( https://www.whonix.org/wiki/Dev/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor also needs an update. )

github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor

set environment variables TOR_SOCKS_SOCKET and TOR_CONTROL_SOCKET 

so Tor Browser connectivity does not break when TPO switches to SocksSocket
https://phabricator.whonix.org/T192
by adrelanos on 08:31PM - 13 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 5 additions and 8 deletions.

github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor

forward /var/run/tor/socks to Whonix-Gateway

by adrelanos on 08:40PM - 13 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 3 additions and 0 deletions.

github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor

create socat unix domain sockets as user debian-tor to solve permission issues

by adrelanos on 06:26PM - 14 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 23 additions and 21 deletions.

comments

changed 1 files with 7 additions and 0 deletions.

changed 1 files with 6 additions and 1 deletions.

by adrelanos on 06:38PM - 14 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 1 additions and 1 deletions.

also create and forward /var/run/tor/control

by adrelanos on 06:45PM - 14 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 4 additions and 0 deletions.

github.com/Whonix/anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor

add support for python-stem Tor Control Socket based authentication 

by adding a functional /var/run/tor/control.authcookie
by adrelanos on 07:44PM - 14 Sep 16
changed 2 files with 3 additions and 4 deletions.

also add functional /var/run/tor/control_auth_cookie and /var/lib/tor/control_auth_cookie

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Patrick:

Should we end lines with CRLF?

End lines with CRLF now.

github.com/Whonix/control-port-filter-python

add support for python-stem Tor control socket based authentication 

- also accept AUTHCHALLANGE Tor control port command
- correctly terminate answers with CRLF
by adrelanos on 07:21PM - 14 Sep 16
changed 1 files with 8 additions and 5 deletions.

Read full topic

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
Added the following to the config.

CONTROL_PORT_FILTER_ALLOW_WILDCARDS=true

CONTROL_PORT_FILTER_WHITELIST=protocolinfo 1
CONTROL_PORT_FILTER_WHITELIST=authchallenge *

Then run the following on a Qubes-Whonix-Gateway.

tor-prompt -i 10.137.3.1:9052

Did not work.

Unable to authenticate: All lines should end with CRLF

Could this be a more general error? Should we end lines with CRLF?

(What I really was doing was trying multi lined commands in context of research control port filter proxy whiltelist wildcard security implications.)

Read full topic

New variable CONTROL_PORT_FILTER_ALLOw_WiLDCARDS. If set, commands containing
random data (ex hidden service ID:port) are passed if an wildcard alias exists
in the commands...

item.title: Control Port Filter Proxy Python (cpfpy) / anon-ws-disable-stacked-tor
item.dc:creator: Patrick
item.description:
[code]
W: control-port-filter-python: systemd-service-file-refers-to-obsolete-target lib/systemd/system/control-port-filter-python.service syslog.target
N: 
N:    The systemd service file refers to an obsolete target.
N:    
N:    Some targets are obsolete by now, e.g. syslog.target or dbus.target. For
N:    example, declaring After=syslog.target is unnecessary by now because
N:    syslog is socket-activated and will therefore be started when needed.
N:    
N:    Severity: normal, Certainty: certain
N:    
N:    Check: systemd, Type: binary
N:[/code]

W: control-port-filter-python: systemd-service-file-refers-to-obsolete-target lib/systemd/system/control-port-filter-python.service syslog.target N: N: The systemd service file refers to an obsolete target. N: N: Some targets are obsolete by now, e.g. syslog.target or dbus.target. For N: example, declaring After=syslog.target is unnecessary by now because N: syslog is socket-activated and will therefore be started when needed. N: N: Severity: normal, Certainty: certain N: N: Check: systemd, Type: binary N:

Read full topic
